user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskSetPriority:
```c
int32 OS_TaskSetPriority(osal_id_t task_id, osal_priority_t new_priority)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        return_code = OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl(&token, new_priority);

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* Use the abstracted priority, not the OS one */
            /* Change the priority in the table as well */
            task->priority = new_priority;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskSetPriority:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct
{
    char            task_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
    osal_task_entry entry_function_pointer;
    osal_task_entry delete_hook_pointer;
    void *          entry_arg;
    osal_stackptr_t stack_pointer;
} OS_task_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, osal_priority_t new_priority)
{
    int os_priority;
    int ret;

    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    if (POSIX_GlobalVars.EnableTaskPriorities)
    {
        /* Change OSAL priority into a priority that will work for this OS */
        os_priority = OS_PriorityRemap(new_priority);

        /*
        ** Set priority
        */
        ret = pthread_setschedprio(impl->id, os_priority);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_setschedprio: Task ID = %lu, prio = %d, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), os_priority, strerror(ret));
            return OS_ERROR;
        }
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint8_t osal_priority_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically, the code does not contain any of the common vendor/compiler extension constructs that would trigger MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 checks, such as:

- __attribute__ or other GCC/clang attributes, __asm__ or inline assembly, or __builtin_* intrinsics
- typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), or GNU nested functions
- __extension__ markers or other compiler-specific pragmas
- compiler-specific storage-class specifiers (for example, __thread) or calling-convention keywords
- non-standard language features like implicit function declarations, anonymous structs/unions in non-standard ways, or non-standard variable-length array usage beyond C standard

The use of pthreads (pthread_setschedprio) and POSIX_GlobalVars, standard fixed-width integer typedefs (int32_t, uint32_t, uint8_t), standard inline function syntax (static inline), preprocessor macros, and pointer/address operators are standard C or POSIX library usage and are not language compiler extensions per se. Therefore there are no code fragments to report for investigation under Rule 1.2.
